modules.name: IxSignal
modules.comments: Module for creating one signal out of another

declarations.comments: Generates a UUID
declarations.title: ixSignalToSignal

modules.name: IxSignal.Extra
modules.comments: Utilities for asynchronously drawing values out of a signal.

declarations.comments: Applies the function only once, when the predicate is satisfied (potentially immediately)
declarations.title: onWhenIx

declarations.comments: With a random key
declarations.title: onWhen

declarations.comments: Applies the handler once when the value exists
declarations.title: onAvailableIx

declarations.comments: Draws the value out when the predicate is matched, potentially immediately
declarations.title: getWhenIx

declarations.comments: Draws the value out when `Just`
declarations.title: getAvailableIx

declarations.comments: Applies the handler only once, on the next change
declarations.title: onNextIx

declarations.comments: Using a random key
declarations.title: onNext

declarations.comments: Draws the value out on the next change
declarations.title: getNextIx

modules.name: IxSignal.Internal
modules.comments:
Indexed signals are similar to normal signals in that they represent a single value at all times,
and can have a set of handlers that react to the value's change. However, indexed signals also
allow for distinguished values for each handler if necessary (where handlers and these indexed
values are indexed by a string). Updating a value for a signal can also be indexed, so the
change is only reflected to that one handler. Likewise, you can broadcast the update.
IxSignals could be useful for many dynamic handlers that need to listen to a shared value -
for instance, the window size, so UI components can react a 'la responsive design at their own
individual volition, while allowing the handler to be unregistered when the user interface
component unmounts.

declarations.comments: Add a handler to the signal, and fire on the current value
declarations.title: subscribe

declarations.comments: Add a handler without an initial fire
declarations.title: subscribeLight

declarations.comments: Add a handler and fire initially, but only fire when the value changes
declarations.title: subscribeDiff

declarations.comments: Add a handler, but only fire when the value changes
declarations.title: subscribeDiffLight

declarations.comments: Add a handler to the signal and fire initially, but with a specific key
declarations.title: subscribeIx

declarations.comments: Add a handler to the signal without firing initially, but with a specific key
declarations.title: subscribeIxLight

declarations.comments: Subscribe a handler to a random UUID key
declarations.title: subscribeWithKey

declarations.comments: Subscribe without initial application
declarations.title: subscribeWithKeyLight

declarations.comments: Add a subscriber to the set, removing and using a specific named value if it exists
declarations.title: subscribeIxWithKey

declarations.comments: Add a subscriber to the set, without applying a value first.
declarations.title: subscribeIxWithKeyLight

declarations.comments: Only respond to changes in signal's value, not submissions in total
declarations.title: subscribeIxWithKeyDiff

declarations.comments: Like `subscribeIxWithKeyDiff`, but without an initial firing
declarations.title: subscribeIxWithKeyDiffLight

declarations.comments: Publish a message to the set of subscribers
declarations.title: set

declarations.comments: Set a distinguished value for the index, storing if a subscriber is absent
declarations.title: setIx

declarations.comments: Only set the value if it differs from the current one - useful if you don't want
declarations.title: setDiff

declarations.comments: Gets the last message published to the subscribers
declarations.title: get

declarations.comments: Attempts to get the last named value, else use the global one.
declarations.title: getIx

declarations.comments: Removes all subscribers
declarations.title: clearSubscribers

declarations.comments: Removes all individual
declarations.title: clearIndividual

declarations.comments: Removes all from both
declarations.title: clear

declarations.comments: Removes a subscriber
declarations.title: deleteSubscriber

declarations.comments: Removes an individual value
declarations.title: deleteIndividual

declarations.comments: Removes both
declarations.title: delete

declarations.comments: Create a signal with a starting value
declarations.title: make

modules.name: Signal
modules.comments:
This module tries to mimic purescript-signal's API, without hiding the fact that new Signals
are _created_ in the process of mapping over their value - this means that if you have dangling
subscribers to the old reference, then it won't get garbage collected.

declarations.comments: Alias for `make`
declarations.title: constant

declarations.comments: Creates a new signal, relaying the next incoming values from the old to the new, after transformation.
declarations.title: map'

declarations.comments: Same as map, but where each transformation might be effectful.
declarations.title: traverse'

modules.name: Signal.Internal
modules.comments:
Signals are a dual concept to Queues - they _always_ have a value that may change,
while a queue represents transient events. This module defines a lower level interface
to a signal - so you can clearly see that registering handlers via `subscribe` is effectful,
as is changing the current value with `set`.

declarations.comments: Add a subscribers to the set
declarations.title: subscribe

declarations.comments: Subscribe without invoking an initial call of the handler
declarations.title: subscribeLight

declarations.comments: Publish a message to the set of subscribers
declarations.title: set

declarations.comments: Gets the last message published to the subscribers
declarations.title: get

declarations.comments: Removes all subscribers
declarations.title: clear

declarations.comments: Create a signal with a starting value
declarations.title: make
